conclusion: Understanding the relationship between the velocity-time graph and the average velocity.
Average velocity is given by the area under the velocity-time graph divided by the time interval.
Car A's velocity-time graph is a curve starting at v1 and increasing to v2.
Area under Car A's curve can be approximated by the area of the triangle formed by the x-axis and the line connecting (0, v1) and (t1, v2).
Car B's velocity-time graph is a curve starting at v1 and decreasing to v2.
Area under Car B's curve can be approximated by the area of the triangle formed by the x-axis and the line connecting (0, v1) and (t1, v2).
Area under the curve for Car A is the area of the triangle with vertices at (0, v1), (t1, v2), and (t1, 0).
Area under the curve for Car B is the area of the triangle with vertices at (0, v1), (t1, v2), and (t1, 0).
Since the areas under the curves are the same, the average velocities are the same.
Velocity of Car A is always increasing, while velocity of Car B is always decreasing.
Car A is gaining speed, while Car B is losing speed, so Car A's average velocity must be greater than Car B's.
Final answer: Car A's average velocity is greater than Car B's average velocity.
